Award.AwardTitle: Balancing Gas Loss, Star Formation, and Black Hole Activity in Cluster Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rukmani Vijayaraghavan is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at the University of Virginia. Galaxies in dense groups and clusters, unlike ordinary field galaxies like the Milky Way, are subject to extreme astrophysical processes that remove their gas and shut down star formation. These processes are far from gentle; many galaxies go through a violent evolutionary phase before settling into their eventual passive gas-poor states. During this phase, star formation and supermassive black hole activity within galaxies can be triggered by strong pressure in the ambient gas. Energy injected by these stars and supermassive black holes can in turn replenish gas lost from galaxies, further continuing this cycle. These processes, mysteriously, operate in the presence of other mechanisms in dense environments that should destroy galactic gas. While there is abundant observational evidence that these processes operate in cluster galaxies, a theoretical understanding of the physics driving the energy cycle in group and cluster galaxies remains elusive. Vijayaraghavan will exploit recent advances in computing and astrophysical software development to carry out a simulations-based investigation into these extreme astrophysical phenomena. She will also run an educational program to promote enthusiasm for computational astrophysics in middle-school-aged girl students. These students will be exposed to the latest scientific developments and techniques in modern astrophysics through computer- and telescope-based activities.

Solving the problem of galaxy evolution in cluster environments requires modeling and disentangling the contribution of multiple simultaneous complex physical phenomena, operating over six orders of magnitude in physical scale. Vijayaraghavan will perform a series of supercomputer simulations using the FLASH code to progressively incorporate multiple physics modules, and use adaptive mesh refinement to focus computational resources on interesting regions. In these simulations, cosmologically realistic red and blue galaxies, including their stellar and gas components, will be allowed to evolve within massive group and cluster environments in the presence of progressively complex physical processes. Based on these simulations, Vijayaraghavan will identify and disentangle the physical mechanisms triggering star formation and black hole activity in cluster galaxies, and investigate the impacts of these processes on cluster galaxy evolution. She will also generate mock observations from simulations to directly compare with radio, optical, and X-ray observations of the hot and cold gas, star formation, and black hole activity in cluster galaxies. This project will use supercomputing resources at the University of Virginia and NSF XSEDE supercomputers. The educational component of this program will be based around summer day camps, where girls will gain an understanding of modern astrophysics through a combination of interactive presentations and hands-on experience with computers and observatory telescopes. The object of these camps will be to inspire girls to pursue careers in STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The goal of the research component of this project was to understand the evolution of the interstellar medium of galaxies in dense cluster environments -- in other words, to understand the properties of galaxies' gas as galaxies are destroyed in clusters and prevented from forming stars. This involves understanding the impact of extreme astrophysical processes in these regions. We used computer simulations to understand how gas is removed from galaxies, as well as how gas can be retained and possibly even form stars.

We simulated ram pressure stripping -- the removal of gas by drag forces --  of hot, X-ray emitting gas from elliptical galaxies, and of cool gas that may form stars from disk galaxies. We studied the effect of thermal conduction -- the heating of gas in galaxies by the hotter gas in the surrounding cluser -- and found that efficient thermal conduction should result in the rapid evaporation of gas from galaxies.

This effect must be suppressed in observed galaxies that do retain gas for significantly longer timescales than that of evaporation, implying the need for a mechanism that counteracts evaporation. We find that magnetic fields can drastically slow down this evaporation by forcing heat to flow along magnetic filed lines, and resulting in the observed structures of galaxy tails in X-ray and radio wavelengths. To study this process, we developed for the first time a magnetic field structure where the gas surrounding the galaxy has a distinct, "shielded" structure compared to that of the gas withing the galaxy.

We also find that galaxies themselves signficantly affect the overall magnetic field structure of galaxy clusters. As galaxies orbit within a massive cluster, they stretch and amplify the local magnetic field -- particularly along their stripped tail and their leading edge. They also inject turbulence into the gas in the intracluster medium.

When disk galaxies like the Milky Way galaxy undergo ram pressure stripping, they can form "jellyfish" galaxies. These are galaxies with stripped tails of gas that are lit up by newly formed stars. We simulated the formation of jellyfish galaxies under a variety of conditions -- supersonic and subsonic galaxy velocities, with and without magnetic fields, and in some models, included the effects of anisotropic thermal conduction to understand the possible conditions under which these systems form long narrow tails and stars.  As in the case with elliptical galaxies, we used for the first time a unique magnetic field geometry where the surrounding cluster magnetic field wraps around or "shields" the galaxy, thereby resulting in two distinct fields.  We find that  magnetic fields are necessary to form the long narrow tails of these galaxies, and that cool, dense, star forming gas is more favored when the magnetic field in the cluster is perpendicular to the direction along which galaxies move. Under certain physical conditions, the magnetic field of the surrounding medium can compress galaxy tails, forming stripped tails that are not bifurcated. Observations of jellyfish galaxy tails can therefore be used to infer the local magnetic field geometry.

Broader Impacts

As part of this project's Broader Impacts, we ran the Girls Exploring the Universe camp once every year in 2016, 2017, and 2018 at the historic McCormick Observatory at the University of Virginia with some additional support from U.Va's Office for Diversity and Equity. The camp consisted of inquiry-based, curiosity-driven, and hands-on activities in a range of topics in astronomy and space sciences -- including a field trip to Green Bank Observatory, home of the world's largest movable radio telescope; an activity to build and drive "Mars Rovers", observing the Sun, understanding the scale of the planets and the System, and more. The girls interacted with women astronomers from graduate students to senior faculty with a range of research expertise.  The object of GETU was to encourage middle school girls, typically between the ages of 11-14, to see themselves as future scientists; girls who attended the camp reported positive views of women in STEM and many expressed interest in future STEM careers.
